choices.text: 50 mg
30.5 mg
12.5 mg

questions.text: How much drug will be left after 6 hours if a patient is given a dose of 200 mg and 75 mg is excreted in 90 minutes. (Assume that the drug follows first-order kinetics)?  (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 30.5 mg

 

This question can be solved by two methods.

 

Method 1: Using the fraction method

In 1st order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time.

75 mg is excreted in 90 mins.

Therefore 75/200 = 3/8th of the drug is eliminated in 90 minutes.

Thus after 90 minutes, 1-3/8 = 5/8th portion of the drug is left behind.

6 hours = 4 * 90 minutes.

Or, in 6 hrs = (5/8) * (5/8) *(5/8)*(5/8)* 200 mg will be left behind

= 30.518 mg will be left behind.

 

Method 2: Using the formula

First we need to determine the elimination rate constant (k) and the half-life (t1/2) of the drug.

We know that 75 mg of the drug is excreted in 90 minutes (1.5 hours). This means that the amount remaining after 1.5 hours is 200 mg - 75 mg = 125 mg.

First, we can use the formula for first-order kinetics to find k:

k = {log (C0/Ct)} / t​

Where:

  • C0 ​is the initial concentration (200 mg)
  • Ct ​is the concentration after time t (125 mg)
  • t is the time in hours (1.5 hours)

k = {log⁡ (200/125)} / 1.5

k={log⁡(1.6)} / 1.5

k ≈ 0.470/1.5

k ≈ 0.313 hr−1

Next, we find the half-life using the relationship between k and t1/2:

t1/2 = 0.693 /k

t1/2 ​= 0.693​/0.313

t1/2 = 2.21 hours

Now, we need to determine the amount of drug left after 6 hours. We use the first-order kinetics formula:

Ct = C0 × e−kt

Where:

  • C0 is the initial concentration (200 mg)
  • k is the elimination rate constant (0.313 hr^-1)
  • t is the time (6 hours)

Ct = 200 × e−0.313×6

Ct = 200 × e−1.878

Ct = 200 × 0.153

Ct ≈ 30.5 mg

questions.text: What is the most bactericidal anti leprotic drug amongst the given drugs? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ofloxacin

 

In general, Rifampicin is the most potent bactericidal anti leprotic drug.

 

But in cases of Rifampicin resistance, we use regimens consisting of Ofloxacin+ Clofazimine + Clarithromycin/Minocycline are used for 24 months.

 

Out of these, the fluoroquinolone Ofloxacin is the most bactericidal anti leprotic drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin: Amoxicillin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against a variety of bacterial infections but is not typically used or effective against Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium that causes leprosy.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is another fluoroquinolone that has broad antibacterial activity, including some activity against Mycobacterium species. However, it is not as potent as Ofloxacin in the treatment of leprosy.

 

Option D. Erythromycin: Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that has some activity against Mycobacterium species but is less effective and less commonly used in the treatment of leprosy compared to Other Options: like Rifampicin and Ofloxacin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ofloxacin is the most bactericidal anti-leprotic drug among the given options, especially used in cases where there is resistance to the standard first-line treatment with Rifampicin.

choices.text: PGP stands for permeability glycoprotein
Also known as CD243
Also known as ABCB1
Also known as MDR2

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about P-glycoprotein? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Also known as MDR2

 

Also known as MDR2 is not true about P-glycoprotein. P-glycoprotein is also known as permeability glycoprotein (PGP), CD243, and ATP-binding cassette sub-family B member 1 (ABCB1). MDR2, on the other hand, is a different protein called multidrug resistance protein 2, which is also involved in drug transport.

 

Other Options:

 

P-glycoprotein (PGP) is a well-known membrane protein that functions as a drug transporter. It is involved in the efflux of drugs and other substances from cells, contributing to multidrug resistance.

 

Option A. PGP stands for permeability glycoprotein: This is true. P-glycoprotein is indeed referred to as permeability glycoprotein.

 

Option B. Also known as CD243: This is true. P-glycoprotein is identified as CD243 in the cluster of differentiation nomenclature.

 

Option C. Also known as ABCB1: This is true. P-glycoprotein is also known as ATP-binding cassette sub-family B member 1 (ABCB1).

 

Educational Objective:

 

P-glycoprotein is known as permeability glycoprotein (PGP), CD243, and ABCB1, but it is not referred to as MDR2. MDR2 is a separate protein involved in drug transport.

choices.text: Amphotericin B

questions.text: For which of the following drugs, absorption is increased after a fatty meal? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Griseofulvin

 

Griseofulvin is an antifungal drug that acts by blocking the microtubules. It is given orally, preferably with a fatty meal, which has been found to increase its absorption. This enhancement in absorption is due to the lipophilic nature of griseofulvin, which allows it to dissolve better in the presence of dietary fats, facilitating its uptake in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication primarily administered intravenously due to poor oral absorption. Its absorption is not significantly affected by meals.

 

Option C. Ampicillin: Ampicillin is an antibiotic that is generally well absorbed on an empty stomach. Food can actually reduce the absorption of ampicillin.

 

Option D. Aspirin: Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory and antipyretic drug. Its absorption is not significantly increased by fatty meals, although taking it with food can help minimize gastrointestinal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs whose absorption increase with meals

Griseofulvin

Statins

Halofantrine

Erlotinib

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a side effect of salbutamol?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypoglycemia

 

Salbutamol is a β2 receptor agonist that is used as a Short Acting Bronchodilator in the relief of acute exacerbations from asthma.

 

It can lead to tachycardia (due to stimulation of the β1 receptors at large doses), Hypokalemia and development of tolerance on long term use due to desensitization of its receptors and in large doses can lead to hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypokalemia: This is a known side effect of salbutamol due to its action on β2 receptors, which increase potassium uptake into cells, resulting in lower serum potassium levels.

 

Option C. Tremors: These are a common side effect of salbutamol due to β2 receptor stimulation in skeletal muscles, leading to muscle tremors.

 

Option D. Tachycardia: Salbutamol, especially at higher doses, can stimulate β1 receptors in the heart, leading to an increased heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salbutamol can cause hypokalemia, tremors, and tachycardia, but it does not cause hypoglycemia. Instead, it can lead to hyperglycemia due to its effect on glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be sold only on prescription from a registered medical practitioner? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Schedule H drugs

 

Under the "Drugs and Cosmetics Act," certain schedules classify drugs based on various criteria, including the need for prescription, potential for abuse, and manufacturing practices.

 

  • Schedule H drugs: These drugs can only be sold with a prescription from a registered medical practitioner. They are labeled with "Rx" written in black color to indicate that they should be dispensed only on prescription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schedule M drugs: These pertain to Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) for pharmaceuticals and do not indicate a requirement for prescription-based sale.

 

Option C. Schedule J drugs: This schedule lists diseases and ailments for which a drug may not claim to prevent or cure. It does not pertain to prescription requirements.

 

Option D. Schedule X drugs: These are psychotropic substances with a high potential for abuse and must be sold with a valid prescription. While Schedule X drugs also require a prescription, the question specifically asks about drugs that should be sold only on prescription from a registered medical practitioner, making Schedule H drugs the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The important schedules under the “Drugs and Cosmetics Act” are:

 

  • Schedule H – The drugs that can be sold only by prescription where Rx is written in black color.
  • Schedule H1 – for antibiotics where Rx is written in red color.
  • Schedule G – Drugs that need labelling as “Dangerous to use except under medical supervision.”
  • Schedule X – Psychotropic drugs that have a high abuse liability and are to be sold with a valid prescription only.
  • Schedule P drug – describes the life period of drugs in months (unless otherwise specified) between the date of manufacture and date of expiry.
  • Schedule M – GMP or Good Manufacturing Practices.
  • Schedule J - List of diseases and ailments which a drug may not claim to prevent or cure

questions.text: The loading dose of a drug is governed primarily by? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Volume of distribution

 

Loading dose = Volume of Distribution * Target plasma concentration.

 

Loading dose is the high initial dose of the drug that is initially given to cover the distribution so that the desired action can take place. In other words, when the time to reach a steady-state is long, it may be desirable to administer a loading dose that promptly raises the concentration of drug in plasma to the target concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clearance: Clearance is a measure of the body's efficiency in eliminating the drug but does not determine the loading dose. It is more relevant to the maintenance dose.

 

Option C. Plasma half-life: The half-life of a drug determines how long it stays in the body but is not directly used to calculate the loading dose.

 

Option D. Bioavailability: Bioavailability refers to the fraction of the administered dose that reaches the systemic circulation. While important for understanding the effective dose, it does not govern the calculation of the loading dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The loading dose of a drug is primarily governed by its volume of distribution, which helps achieve the desired plasma concentration quickly, especially when the drug has a long half-life.

questions.text: Therapeutic index is used for assessing which of the following factors? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Safety

 

Therapeutic Index tells us about the margin of safety for a drug. It is calculated as follows:

 

Therapeutic index = TD50/ED50

 

• TD50 (Median toxic dose) = Dose at which there were toxic effects at 50% of the subjects

• ED50 (Median effect dose) = Dose required to produce a therapeutic effect in 50% of the individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Efficacy: Efficacy refers to the maximum effect a drug can produce, regardless of dose. The therapeutic index does not measure this.

 

Option C. Potency: Potency is the amount of drug needed to produce a given effect. It is not assessed by the therapeutic index.

 

Option D. Toxicity: While toxicity is a component of the therapeutic index (TD50), the index itself is used to measure the safety margin rather than toxicity alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of a drug, indicating the margin between effective and toxic doses. A higher therapeutic index means a drug is safer, with a lower risk of adverse effects at therapeutic doses.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause flagellated pigmentation of skin? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bleomycin

 

Bleomycin is the chemotherapeutic drug that is known to cause flagellated hyperpigmentation in the skin. Another side effect of Bleomycin is pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Doxorubicin: This chemotherapeutic agent is known for causing cardiotoxicity and myelosuppression, but it does not typically cause flagellated pigmentation of the skin.

 

Option C. Vincristine: This drug is associated with neurotoxicity, particularly peripheral neuropathy, but it does not cause flagellated hyperpigmentation.

 

Option D. Minocycline: This antibiotic can cause skin pigmentation, but it is not typically flagellated. The pigmentation with minocycline tends to be more diffuse and can affect the skin, nails, and other tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleomycin is known to cause flagellated hyperpigmentation of the skin as a unique side effect. It can also cause pulmonary fibrosis, making it important to monitor patients for respiratory symptoms during treatment.

choices.text: a, b and c
d and e
a, d and e
a, b and d

questions.text:
Aspirin and phenobarbitone are acidic drugs whereas diazepam is a basic drug. Which of the following statement/s about these drugs is/are true?(AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. Aspirin is present mainly in non-ionized form in stomach, hence can be easily absorbed
  2. Diazepam is mostly absorbed form intestine
  3. Phenobarbitone can be absorbed from stomach but most of the absorption occurs in small intestine due to its large surface area
  4. No drug is absorbed in large intestine due to its very low surface area
  5. Diseases decreasing the transit time of drugs like diarrhea will increase the drug absorption in small intestine
questions.solution:
Ans. A. a, b and c

 

Absorption across any membrane depends on lipid solubility. Non-ionized form of drugs is lipid soluble and can easily cross the membranes.

 

 

So, basic drugs like diazepam are absorbed maximally from intestine (option b).

 

  • Acidic drugs although are mainly non-ionized in stomach but are absorbed very less because the gastric emptying time is very small. So, these are quickly transferred to intestine. These become ionized in intestine due to alkaline medium. However, due to their longer time of stay in intestine and very large surface area as compared to stomach even the small amount of their non-ionised form contributes to significant absorption. So, practically every drug (whether acidic or basic) are absorbed more in intestine as compared to stomach. 
  • Aspirin (acidic drug) – It is non-ionised in stomach and hence easily absorbed.
  • Diazepam (basic drug)- It is non-ionised in intestine, hence easily absorbed.
  • Phenobarbitone (acidic drug)- Any drug is maximally absorbed in intestine due to large surface area of intestine.
  • Surface area of large intestine is large, so statement (d) is wrong.
  • Diarrhea decreases the transit time of drug, hence decreases the absorption as the time available for absorption decreases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option D. This statement is incorrect. The large intestine does have a considerable surface area and can absorb drugs, although to a lesser extent compared to the small intestine.

 

Option E. This statement is also incorrect. Diseases that decrease the transit time, such as diarrhea, reduce the absorption of drugs because the time available for absorption is decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-ionized forms of drugs are more lipid-soluble and can cross membranes more easily. Acidic drugs like aspirin and phenobarbitone are primarily non-ionized in the stomach but are absorbed mainly in the intestine due to its large surface area. Basic drugs like diazepam are absorbed maximally from the intestine.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/20-21

questions.text:
Mention the true statement/s about digoxin toxicity:(AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. Earliest manifestation of digoxin toxicity is gastrointestinal symptoms
  2. Nonspecific vision changes may be noted in digoxin toxicity
  3. Early toxicity may not correlate with serum levels
  4. Neurological symptoms may occur without corresponding cardiovascular changes
  5. Hypokalemia is associated with increased risk of toxicity
questions.solution:
Ans. A. All are true

 

  • Most common and earliest adverse effect of digoxin is nausea and vomiting (option a).
  • Most common arrhythmia seen in digoxin overdose is ventricular bigeminy.
  • Other adverse effects of digoxin include Gynecomastia and Vision defects (initially non-specific and later yellow vision): Option b
  • Early toxicity may not correlate with serum levels because Digoxin has very high volume of distribution (~450L); So when digoxin reaches heart the plasma concentration may not be high.: Option c
  • Hypokalemia increases the risk of toxicity as the binding site of digoxin and K+ are same on the Na+ K+ pump. So, normally K inhibits the binding of digoxin to Na K pump. When K is less (hypokalemia), binding of digoxin increases and toxicity can result.
  • However, Note that Digoxin toxicity causes hyperkalemia (due to inhibition of Na K pump, K+ cannot enter inside cells and remain in blood, hence hyperkalemia occurs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

All statements about digoxin toxicity, including the earliest manifestations, vision changes, correlation with serum levels, neurological symptoms, and the association with hypokalemia, are true.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/560

questions.text: Clostridium difficile diarrhoea is most commonly associated with? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aminopenicillins

 

  • Clostridium difficile diarrhea is a super-infection also called as Pseudomembranous colitis.
  • Most common cause is 3rd generation Cephalosporins
  • Other causes include Clindamycin, Aminopenicillins (Ampicillin and Amoxycillin), and Fluoroquinolones.
  • DOC for treatment of PMC is fidaxomicin now.
  • Stool transplant can also be done.
  • Monoclonal antibody against toxin of C.difficile is Bezlotoxumab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aminoglycosides: These can also lead to C. difficile diarrhea, but they are less commonly the cause compared to aminopenicillins and third-generation cephalosporins.

 

Option C. Macrolides: Macrolides are less likely to cause C. difficile diarrhea compared to aminopenicillins, third-generation cephalosporins, clindamycin, and fluoroquinolones.

 

Option D. Carbapenems: Carbapenems are broad-spectrum antibiotics but are not commonly associated with C. difficile diarrhea. Their impact on the gut flora is less significant in this context compared to aminopenicillins and other antibiotics mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile diarrhea, also known as pseudomembranous colitis, is commonly associated with aminopenicillins such as ampicillin and amoxicillin. Treatment includes fidaxomicin and potentially stool transplants, with bezlotoxumab available as a monoclonal antibody against the toxin of C. difficile.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/744

questions.text: Preferred drug for the treatment of a 48-year-old man with uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension without any associated co-morbidity is (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chlorthalidone

 

  • Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic that is highly effective in lowering blood pressure and is often recommended as the preferred first-line treatment for uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension. It has a longer duration of action compared to other thiazides, such as hydrochlorothiazide, making it particularly effective in managing hypertension over a 24-hour period.
  • According to ACC Guidelines and JNC 8 Guidelines, the DOC for hypertension is Thiazides (preferred diuretic).
  • Apart from thiazides, the other first line drugs for hypertension are-
  • ACE Inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Triamterene: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic. It is primarily used in combination with other diuretics to prevent hypokalemia but is not recommended as a first-line treatment for hypertension.

 

Option C. Spironolactone: Another potassium-sparing diuretic, primarily used in conditions such as heart failure, hyperaldosteronism, and resistant hypertension, not as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated hypertension.

 

Option D. Furosemide: This is a loop diuretic, which is typically used in conditions such as congestive heart failure, renal insufficiency, and edema. It is not recommended as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated hypertension due to its short duration of action and the potential for significant electrolyte disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension without any associated comorbidities, thiazide diuretics, particularly chlorthalidone, are the preferred first-line agents according to ACC and JNC 8 guidelines.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/615

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are adverse effect of SGLT2 inhibitors? (AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

1. Ketoacidosis

2. Urosepsis

3. Fournier’s gangrene

4. Angioedema
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1, 2 and 3 are correct

 

SGLT-2 INHIBITORS

 

  • Sodium Glucose Transporter 2 (also called SGLT2)  is a transporter for reabsorption of glucose and Na+. It is present in PCT of nephrons. Drug inhibiting this transporter are Canagliflozin, Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin, Ertugliflozin etc.
  • By inhibiting the reabsorption of glucose, these drugs result in glucosuria. This can result in urinary tract infections (including Urosepsis) and genital tract infections like Fournier’s gangrene.
  • If used in type 1 diabetes, these decrease the blood sugar by causing glucosuria. The patient usually decreases the dose of insulin or may altogether stop using insulin as blood sugar levels are within required range. However, type 1 diabetes has absolute insulin deficiency. Insulin not only controls blood sugar but is also required for metabolism of ketone bodies. If the person stops using insulin, it may result in Ketoacidosis. Hence, SGLT-2 inhibitors are contra-indicated in Type 1 diabetes mellitus.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Angioedema: Angioedema is not a recognized adverse effect of SGLT2 inhibitors. This condition is more commonly associated with other drug classes, such as ACE inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary adverse effects of SGLT2 inhibitors include ketoacidosis, urosepsis, and Fournier's gangrene, while angioedema is not associated with these medications.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/301

choices.text: Protects the acid labile drug from gastric acidity
Protects the gastric mucosa from irritant effects of certain drugs
Prolongs the half-life of the drug

questions.text: Many drugs are given as enteric coated tablets. All of the following are the advantages of enteric coating of drugs EXCEPT? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prolongs the half-life of the drug

 

Enteric coatings on tablets protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects, and deliver drugs distal to the stomach. However, they do not prolong the half-life of a drug, which is determined by the drug's metabolism and elimination from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Enteric-coated drugs are designed with a special coating that resists dissolution in the acidic environment of the stomach. This coating dissolves instead in the more alkaline environment of the small intestine. The primary purposes of this enteric coating are:

 

Option A. Protect the acid-labile drug from gastric acidity: Some drugs are unstable in the acidic environment of the stomach and can be degraded before they have a chance to be absorbed. Enteric coating protects these drugs from the acidic gastric environment, ensuring they reach the intestine, where they can be absorbed effectively.

 

Option B. Protect the gastric mucosa from the irritant effects of certain drugs: Certain drugs can irritate the gastric mucosa, leading to discomfort or even ulcers. Enteric coating prevents these drugs from being released in the stomach, thereby reducing the risk of gastric irritation.

 

Option D. Deliver drugs distal to the stomach: Enteric coating is also used to ensure that a drug is released in the intestine rather than the stomach, which can be important for drugs that are intended to act in the intestine or are better absorbed from the intestinal lining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enteric coating is primarily used to protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects, and ensure drug delivery distal to the stomach. It does not prolong the half-life of the drug.

questions.text: A patient who was on antiepileptics for the management of seizure disorder started having visual disturbance. Evaluation reveals the contraction of the visual field. The drug responsible is likely to be? (AIIMS NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vigabatrin

 

Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic that works by inhibiting GABA Transaminase. It is used for the treatment of infantile spasms. It is known to cause visual field constriction in some patients. This adverse effect is thought to be due to the drug's influence on the retina and the central nervous system. Vigabatrin is particularly associated with bilateral concentric visual field constriction, and patients on this medication are often monitored with regular visual field testing.

 

Mnemonic

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenobarbitone: This is a barbiturate used to treat epilepsy, but it is not commonly associated with visual field defects. Its side effects may include sedation, dizziness, and cognitive changes, but not specifically visual disturbances like those described.

 

Option C. Ethosuximide: Primarily used for absence seizures, ethosuximide is not typically associated with visual field contractions. Its side effects can include gastrointestinal disturbances, drowsiness, and headaches.

 

Option D. Levetiracetam: Commonly used in various forms of epilepsy, levetiracetam's side effects can include drowsiness, weakness, and behavioral changes, but it is not commonly associated with significant visual field disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic drug associated with visual field contraction, requiring regular monitoring of visual fields in patients receiving this medication.

choices.text: Bradycardia with AV block
Torsades’ de pointes

questions.text: A patient was taking metoprolol for hypertension but blood pressure was not controlled. Verapamil was added to the regimen. Which of the following adverse effect is likely to be present with combination? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bradycardia with AV block
 

  • Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that is commonly used to hypertension, heart failure, and arrhythmias. It works by slowing down the heart rate and reducing the heart's demand for oxygen.
  • Verapamil, on the other hand, is a calcium channel blocker used for similar indications as metoprolol. It reduces the heart rate and has a negative inotropic effect (reduces the force of heart muscle contraction), and can affect the electrical conduction in the heart.
  • When used together, metoprolol and verapamil can have additive effects on the heart rate and atrioventricular (AV) nodal conduction. This can lead to:
    • Bradycardia: An abnormally slow heart rate.
    • AV block: A delay or complete block in the electrical impulse conduction through the AV node of the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torsades de pointes: This is a specific type of ventricular tachycardia that is not typically associated with the combination of metoprolol and verapamil. It is more often related to medications that prolong the QT interval.

 

Option C. Tachycardia: This is an increased heart rate, which is an unlikely side effect of combining metoprolol and verapamil, as both tend to slow the heart rate.

 

Option D. Ventricular fibrillation: While this is a serious cardiac arrhythmia, it is not a typical side effect of combining metoprolol and verapamil. It's more commonly associated with ischemic heart disease or other structural heart problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of metoprolol and verapamil can lead to significant bradycardia and AV block due to their additive effects on slowing heart rate and AV nodal conduction.

choices.text: Ejaculation
Dilation of bronchus
Increased cardiac contractility

questions.text: Muscarinic receptor stimulation primarily causes which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Erection

 

  • Parasympathetic (muscarinic) stimulation result in erection whereas sympathetic stimulation causes ejaculation.
  • Parasympathetic system causes bronchoconstriction whereas sympathetic system result in bronchodilation.
  • Increase in cardiac contractility is primarily action of beta 1 receptors of the heart.

 

Mnemonic

 

Point and Shoot:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ejaculation: Ejaculation is primarily mediated by the sympathetic nervous system, not the parasympathetic system. Thus, muscarinic receptor stimulation does not cause ejaculation.

 

Option C. Dilation of bronchus: The parasympathetic system causes bronchoconstriction. Bronchodilation is mediated by the sympathetic nervous system.

 

Option D. Increased cardiac contractility: Increased cardiac contractility is primarily an action of beta-1 adrenergic receptors, which are part of the sympathetic nervous system. Muscarinic receptor stimulation generally results in decreased heart rate and contractility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscarinic receptor stimulation is associated with parasympathetic responses such as erection, while sympathetic stimulation is responsible for ejaculation, bronchodilation, and increased cardiac contractility.

questions.text: Rosuvastatin should not be combined with which of the following drugs? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Clarithromycin

 

  • Statins are metabolized by CYP3A4 enzyme, which is inhibited by clarithromycin. The plasma levels of statins may rise to high levels if used with clarithromycin, resulting in serious adverse effects like myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxycodone: Oxycodone is an opioid analgesic used for pain management. It does not interact significantly with rosuvastatin and does not affect its metabolism.

 

Option C. Adalimumab: Adalimumab is a monoclonal antibody used to treat autoimmune conditions. It does not interfere with the metabolism of rosuvastatin and therefore is not associated with increased risk of myopathy when used in combination.

 

Option D. Rivoraxaban: Rivaroxaban is an anticoagulant used to prevent and treat blood clots. It does not interact with the metabolism of rosuvastatin and does not pose a risk of increased myopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs increasing the risk of statin induced myopathy are:

 

  • Amiodarone
  • Gemfibrozil
  • HIV protease inhibitors like saquinavir, ritonavir etc.
  • Clarithromycin
  • Itraconazole

choices.text: Ciprofloxacin and tinidazole
Only ciprofloxacin
Only ORS
Ciprofloxacin, tinidazole and ORS

questions.text: A young male developed 5 episodes of loose stools 2 hours after eating in a restaurant. He is afebrile and has mild dehydration. What should be the treatment? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only ORS

 

Management of diarrhea in an afebrile patient is mainly based on the presence or absence of dehydration. In case of no dehydration or some dehydration, we can manage it using only ORS. If there is severe dehydration, then IV fluids have to be used. There is no role of antibiotics in such case. Empirical antibiotics are used only in case of febrile patients. If only bacterial etiology is suspected, the Ciprofloxacin is used, and it amoebiasis or giardiasis is suspected, then Metronidazole is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciprofloxacin and tinidazole: This combination is used for treating bacterial and protozoal infections. However, it is not indicated here because the patient is afebrile and the condition is likely self-limiting.

 

Option B. Only ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic used for bacterial infections. Since the patient is afebrile and has mild dehydration, there is no indication for antibiotic therapy. ORS alone is sufficient.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin, tinidazole and ORS: This combination is unnecessary and potentially harmful. Overuse of antibiotics can lead to resistance and other side effects. The primary treatment needed is rehydration with ORS

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a young male with afebrile, mild dehydration due to acute diarrhea, the appropriate treatment is oral rehydration solution (ORS) to replace lost fluids and electrolytes. Antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a suspicion of bacterial infection with severe symptoms or fever.

questions.text: Atropine is indicated in all of the following poisonings except? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Endrin

 

Atropine is an anticholinergic agent used to counteract the effects of excessive acetylcholine, such as those seen in organophosphate and carbamate poisoning. It works by blocking the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors, thereby alleviating symptoms of excessive cholinergic activity like salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, and emesis (SLUDGE syndrome).
 

  • Endrin is an organochloride pesticide, primarily causing neurotoxic effects, including seizures. The mechanism of toxicity involves disruption of the central nervous system rather than the cholinergic system. Therefore, atropine is not effective in managing Endrin poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Baygon: Atropine is indicated as it counters the acetylcholine accumulation due to acetylcholinesterase inhibition caused by organophosphates/carbamates in Baygon.

 

Option B. TIK 20: As an organophosphate, TIK 20 poisoning results in excessive acetylcholine, where atropine is beneficial.

 

Option C. Parathion: Parathion is an organophosphate pesticide causing acetylcholinesterase inhibition, making atropine an effective treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endrin is an organochloride pesticide. It leads to neurotoxicity, and in that case, Atropine cannot be used in the treatment. Parathion and TIK20 are organophosphates and baygon is a combination of organophosphate and carbamate. For all of these poisonings, atropine is the mainstay of management.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female came for treatment of infertility to OPD, Bromocriptine was prescribed. What could be the possible reason? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hyperprolactinemia

 

Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that acts on D2 receptors. It is effective in reducing prolactin secretion, which is useful in treating hyperprolactinemia. Elevated levels of prolactin can inhibit the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), leading to decreased levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), which can cause anovulation and infertility.

 

Mechanism of Bromocriptine:

 

  • Action: Bromocriptine stimulates D2 dopamine receptors.
  • Effect: Decreases prolactin secretion from the pituitary gland.
  • Result: Reduction in prolactin levels can restore normal GnRH secretion, normalizing FSH and LH levels and resuming ovulatory cycles, thus addressing infertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PCOD (Polycystic Ovarian Disease): PCOD is characterized by multiple cysts in the ovaries, insulin resistance, and hyperandrogenism. Treatment usually involves lifestyle changes, metformin, or hormonal therapies, not specifically bromocriptine unless associated with hyperprolactinemia.

 

Option C. Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism: This condition involves low levels of FSH and LH due to hypothalamic or pituitary dysfunction. Treatment often includes gonadotropins or pulsatile GnRH therapy. Bromocriptine is not indicated unless hyperprolactinemia is a contributing factor.

 

Option D. PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease): PID is an infection of the female reproductive organs. Treatment typically involves antibiotics. Bromocriptine has no role in treating PID.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bromocriptine is a Dopaminergic agonist that leads to a decrease in the secretion of Prolactin by its action on the D2 dopaminergic receptors of the Nigrostriatal Pathway. Hyperprolactinemia can cause infertility by inhibiting the release of GnRH from the hypothalamus, leading to a decrease in the levels of FSH and LH.

questions.text: Which is a mood stabilizer with an anti-suicidal role? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lithium

 

Lithium is the only mood stabilizer that has been consistently shown to have an anti-suicidal effect in patients with bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder. Numerous studies have demonstrated that lithium reduces the risk of suicide and suicide attempts. It is considered the gold standard for mood stabilization, particularly in bipolar disorder, due to its efficacy in preventing both manic and depressive episodes.

 

Mechanism of Lithium:

 

  • Mood Stabilization: Lithium modulates neurotransmission by affecting various neurotransmitter pathways, including serotonin and norepinephrine.
  • Neuroprotective Effects: Lithium enhances neurogenesis and has neuroprotective effects, potentially contributing to its anti-suicidal properties.
  • Reduction in Aggression and Impulsivity: Lithium has been shown to reduce aggression and impulsivity, which are risk factors for suicide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder, particularly in patients with rapid cycling or mixed states. However, it does not have a proven anti-suicidal effect.

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Lamotrigine is effective as a mood stabilizer, particularly in preventing depressive episodes in bipolar disorder. While it helps in mood stabilization, it does not have a specific anti-suicidal effect.

 

Option D. Valproate: Valproate is another anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer used in bipolar disorder, especially effective in rapid cyclers. It does not have an established anti-suicidal role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lithium is unique among mood stabilizers for its anti-suicidal properties. It significantly reduces the risk of suicide and is effective in stabilizing mood in patients with bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder. Valproate is the drug of choice in rapid cyclers, whereas Lamotrigine is effective as a mood stabilizer in Depression.

choices.text: Blurred vision
Steven Johnson Syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is not an idiosyncratic reaction of carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Blurred vision

 

Idiosyncrasy is defined as a genetically determined abnormal reactivity to a drug. The drug interacts with some unique feature of the individual, not found in majority of the subjects and produces uncharacteristic reactions. As such the type of the reaction is restricted to individuals with a particular genotype.

 

Idiosyncratic Reactions of Carbamazepine:

 

  • Agranulocytosis: This is a serious idiosyncratic reaction where the drug causes a significant drop in white blood cells, particularly neutrophils, leading to a higher risk of infection.
  • Rash: Skin reactions, including rashes, are common idiosyncratic reactions to carbamazepine. These can range from mild to severe.
  • Steven Johnson Syndrome (SJS): Although rare, carbamazepine can cause severe skin reactions like SJS, which is a serious condition involving the skin and mucous membranes and requires immediate medical attention.

 

Non-Idiosyncratic Reactions:

 

  • Blurred Vision: This is a common side effect of carbamazepine related to its pharmacological action and dose rather than an idiosyncratic reaction. Blurred vision typically occurs due to the drug's effects on the central nervous system and is not unique to specific individuals based on genetic or other idiosyncratic factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Agranulocytosis: Agranulocytosis is a potentially life-threatening idiosyncratic reaction associated with carbamazepine, characterized by a significant reduction in granulocytes, a type of white blood cell.

 

Option C. Rash: Skin rashes are common idiosyncratic reactions to carbamazepine and can vary in severity from mild to severe.

 

Option D. Steven Johnson Syndrome: SJS is a rare but severe idiosyncratic reaction to carbamazepine, involving extensive skin and mucous membrane damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blurred vision is not an idiosyncratic reaction of carbamazepine; it is a common dose-related side effect. Idiosyncratic reactions to carbamazepine include agranulocytosis, rash, and Steven Johnson Syndrome, which are unpredictable and occur due to individual genetic predispositions.

questions.text: Which of the following is gametocidal to all the species causing malaria? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Primaquine

 

Primaquine is gametocidal to all species causing malaria. It inhibits transmission of malaria. Artemisinin also have high gametocidal activity against all the species.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • Primaquine interferes with the mitochondrial electron transport chain in the parasite, leading to the death of gametocytes and hypnozoites (dormant liver forms in Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale).
  • By eliminating gametocytes, primaquine helps reduce the spread of malaria within a community.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloroquine: is primarily effective against the erythrocytic forms of Plasmodium species but does not have gametocidal activity against all species. It is not effective against the dormant liver forms or the gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Option C. Quinine: is effective against the asexual blood stages of Plasmodium species but lacks significant activity against the gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum. It does not have a broad gametocidal effect against all species.

 

Educational Objective

 

Primaquine is the antimalarial drug that is gametocidal to all Plasmodium species, making it essential for preventing the transmission of malaria and addressing relapses in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale infections.

choices.text: - 2 degree Celsius
0 degree Celsius
2-6 degree Celsius
8-15 degree Celsius

questions.text: A drug label suggests storage in a 'cool' place. What is the temperature at which this drug is to be stored? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 8-15 degree Celsius

 

When a drug label suggests storing the medication in a 'cool' place, it refers to a specific temperature range to ensure the drug's stability and efficacy. According to standard pharmaceutical guidelines:

 

  • Cool Place: This term specifically means storing the drug at a temperature range of 8-15 degrees Celsius. This temperature range helps to preserve the drug's properties without freezing it or exposing it to room temperature, which could lead to degradation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. -2 degrees Celsius: This temperature range is considered freezing. Storing drugs at this temperature could cause them to freeze, which is inappropriate for many medications unless specifically indicated.

 

Option B. 0 degrees Celsius: This temperature is the freezing point of water and is also considered freezing storage, which is not suitable for most medications unless specified.

 

Option C. 2-6 degrees Celsius: This range is typically referred to as refrigeration. While some drugs need to be stored in a refrigerator, 'cool place' storage does not imply refrigeration but rather a slightly warmer range than typical refrigeration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs labeled to be stored in a 'cool' place should be kept at a temperature of 8-15 degrees Celsius to ensure their stability and effectiveness. This is neither freezing nor typical room temperature, but a moderate cool environment.

questions.text: A patient with AIDS was treated with zidovudine, lamivudine, indinavir, ketoconazole and cotrimoxazole. He developed nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia and insulin resistance. Which of the drugs could have been the cause? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Indinavir

 

Indinavir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. It is known for several side effects, which include nephrolithiasis (kidney stones), central obesity, hyperlipidemia, and insulin resistance. These adverse effects are part of the metabolic complications often associated with protease inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is an antifungal agent that does not typically cause nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, or insulin resistance. Its side effects are more related to hepatotoxicity, adrenal insufficiency, and drug interactions due to CYP3A4 inhibition.

 

Option C. Lamivudine: Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. It is not commonly associated with nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, or insulin resistance. Its side effects can include lactic acidosis and hepatic steatosis, but these are less common.

 

Option D. Zidovudine: Zidovudine, another NRTI, is associated with side effects such as anemia, neutropenia, and myopathy but not with the specific metabolic complications listed (nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indinavir, a protease inhibitor used in HIV/AIDS treatment, is the drug responsible for causing nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, and insulin resistance among the medications listed.

questions.text: If carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, what adverse effect is risked?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hepatotoxicity

 

  • Valproate is metabolized by CYP450 enzymes into a minor metabolite, which is hepatotoxic.
  • Enzyme inducers like carbamazepine phenytoin and Phenobarbital can induce the microsomal enzyme and increase production of this metabolite. This increases the risk of hepatotoxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatitis: While valproate is associated with a risk of pancreatitis, the addition of carbamazepine does not specifically increase this risk. Pancreatitis is a rare but serious side effect of valproate alone.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: Thrombocytopenia can be a side effect of valproate, but it is not specifically increased by the addition of carbamazepine. Thrombocytopenia results from bone marrow suppression, which is not directly affected by carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Hyperammonemia: Hyperammonemia is a known side effect of valproate and can lead to encephalopathy. However, carbamazepine does not exacerbate this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, there is an increased risk of hepatotoxicity due to the induction of cytochrome P450 enzymes by carbamazepine, leading to increased production of a hepatotoxic metabolite of valproate.

choices.text: Cell wall synthesis inhibitor
Folic acid synthesis inhibitor
Protein synthesis inhibitor
Cell membrane inhibitor

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of dapsone, considering that it is used in the treatment of leprosy, fungal infections and, also for immunomodulatory actions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Folic acid synthesis inhibitor

 

Dapsone is a sulfone antibiotic that works by inhibiting the enzyme dihydropteroate synthase. This enzyme is crucial for the synthesis of dihydropteroic acid, a precursor in the folic acid synthesis pathway. By competitively inhibiting dihydropteroate synthase, dapsone prevents the formation of dihydropteroic acid from para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and pteridine, ultimately disrupting the production of folic acid, which is essential for bacterial growth and replication.

 

This mechanism makes dapsone effective in the treatment of leprosy caused by Mycobacterium leprae and also contributes to its use in certain fungal infections and its immunomodulatory actions, such as in the treatment of dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cell wall synthesis inhibitor: Drugs that inhibit cell wall synthesis, such as penicillin’s and cephalosporins, target the synthesis of peptidoglycan, an essential component of bacterial cell walls. Dapsone does not act via this mechanism.

 

Option C. Protein synthesis inhibitor: Protein synthesis inhibitors, such as tetracyclines and macrolides, interfere with the bacterial ribosome's ability to produce proteins. Dapsone does not inhibit protein synthesis.

 

Option D. Cell membrane inhibitor: Drugs like polymyxins disrupt bacterial cell membranes, leading to cell death. Dapsone does not affect the cell membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dapsone is a competitive inhibitor of Dihydropteroate synthase that is required in the step of conversion of PABA + Pteridine into Dihydropteroic acid, which is the first step in the synthesis of folic acid.

questions.text: What dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1:1000 I.M. - 0.5 ml

 

Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Like all the opioids, tramadol acts as an analgesic drug by stimulating mu opioid receptors. Apart from this, the additional analgesic mechanism of tramadol is? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serotonin and nor-adrenaline reuptake inhibition

 

Tramadol is an atypical opioid analgesic that not only acts by stimulating mu opioid receptors, like other opioids, but also has an additional mechanism of action. This dual mechanism contributes to its analgesic effect.

 

  • Mu Opioid Receptor Agonism: Tramadol binds to mu opioid receptors, which are part of the body's endogenous pain relief system. Activation of these receptors leads to pain relief.
  • Serotonin and Noradrenaline Reuptake Inhibition: Unlike typical opioids, tramadol also inhibits the reuptake of serotonin (5-HT) and noradrenaline (NA). This increases the levels of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, enhancing their action. This mechanism activates the monoaminergic descending inhibitory pathways in the spinal cord, which further contributes to pain relief.

 

Due to its unique mechanism, tramadol's analgesic action is only partially reversed by naloxone, an opioid antagonist, indicating that non-opioid mechanisms also play a significant role in its pain-relieving effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anticholinergic: Tramadol does not have anticholinergic properties. Anticholinergic drugs block the action of acetylcholine in the brain and are not related to the analgesic mechanism of tramadol.

 

Option C. Antihistaminic: Tramadol does not act as an antihistamine. Antihistamines are used primarily to treat allergic reactions and have no significant role in pain relief through histamine receptor antagonism.

 

Option D. Serotonin and dopamine reuptake inhibition: While tramadol does inhibit serotonin reuptake, it does not inhibit dopamine reuptake significantly. Its main additional mechanism of analgesia is through the inhibition of serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tramadol provides pain relief not only through mu opioid receptor agonism but also by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and noradrenaline, thereby activating the descending inhibitory pain pathways in the spinal cord.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/504

questions.text: Non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in all of the following conditions except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Male infertility

 

Pulsatile exposure to GnRH induces FSH/LH secretion while sustained exposure de-sensitizes the receptors resulting in decrease in secretion of gonadotropins. Therefore, non-pulsatile (continuous) GnRH agonists are given when we want to decrease the sex hormones.

 

Indications:-

 

  •  Prostatic carcinoma
  •  Endometriosis
  •  Precocious puberty
  •  Fibroid

 

But in case of male infertility, more testosterone is required to induce spermatogenesis, so GnRH agonists are given in pulsatile manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: In endometriosis, continuous GnRH agonists are used to lower estrogen levels, which helps reduce the growth of endometrial tissue and alleviate symptoms.

 

Option C. Central precocious puberty: Continuous GnRH agonists are used to decrease sex hormone levels, thereby delaying early onset puberty.

 

Option D. Prostate cancer: Continuous GnRH agonists reduce testosterone levels, which helps in managing prostate cancer by slowing down the growth of cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-pulsatile (continuous) GnRH agonists are used to decrease sex hormone levels in conditions such as endometriosis, central precocious puberty, and prostate cancer. In male infertility, pulsatile GnRH agonists are used to increase testosterone and induce spermatogenesis.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 262,263

questions.text: All of the following can be used to decreased intraocular pressure in glaucoma except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dexamethasone

 

Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid. Corticosteroids are contraindicated in glaucoma because they can lead to an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP). This rise in IOP can exacerbate glaucoma and potentially cause further damage to the optic nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannitol: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic and is the drug of choice for acute congestive glaucoma when administered intravenously. It decreases IOP by creating an osmotic gradient, which helps to draw fluid out of the eye, thereby reducing congestion.

 

Option B. Methazolamide: Methazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It decreases the production of aqueous humor in the eye, which in turn reduces intraocular pressure. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are effective in managing glaucoma.

 

Option C. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. It decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. Alpha-2 agonists are commonly used in the treatment of glaucoma.

  

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note - Dexamethasone is contraindicated in glaucoma

 

Reference: KDT 8th/ 318, 167, 170

choices.text: 5HT4 agonist
5HT2b agonist
5HT2b antagonist
5HT1a partial agonist

questions.text: Prucalopride is a (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 5HT4 agonist

 

PRUCALOPRIDE

 

  • It is a selective 5-HT4 receptor agonist approved recently for the treatment of chronic constipation, when other laxatives fail to provide adequate relief.
  • It activates pre-junctional 5-HT4 receptors on intrinsic enteric neurons to enhance release of the excitatory transmitter ACh. It, thereby promotes the propulsive contractions in ileum and more prominently in colon.
  • Prucalopride is shown to have negligible affinity for cardiac K+ channels. It is therefore, believed to be free of cardiovascular risk. No Q-T prolongation has been noted during clinical trial. 


Educational objective:

 

Prucalopride is a selective 5-HT4 receptor agonist used for the treatment of chronic constipation, working by enhancing acetylcholine release to promote intestinal motility without significant cardiovascular risks.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/724

choices.text: Calcium Channel Blocker action
Nitric oxide mediated vasodilation

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of ischemic heart disease. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5-HT agonist

 

Chest pain in an elderly woman with a history of ischemic heart disease, who is on treatment for migraine, could potentially be linked to the mechanism of action of her migraine medication. Among the options given 5-HT agonists can cause this adverse effect. Triptans and ergotamine are a group of drugs that are used in acute attacks of migraine. They act on 5HT1B/1D receptors as agonist and cause vasoconstriction of the blood vessels. Therefore, they should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease as they can precipitate myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-HT Antagonist: Serotonin (5-HT) antagonists like cyproheptadine and methysergide etc are used for prophylaxis of migraine (not in treatment). These drugs are not commonly associated with causing chest pain or exacerbating ischemic heart disease.

 

Option C. Calcium Channel Blocker Action: While calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are used in migraine prophylaxis, they are generally heart-protective and used in the treatment of angina and hypertension due to their vasodilatory effects. It's unlikely that CCBs would cause chest pain.

 

Option D. Nitric Oxide Mediated Vasodilation: Nitric oxide donors (like nitrates) are used in the treatment of angina due to their vasodilatory effects. They are not typically used in migraine treatment, and their vasodilatory action would be more likely to relieve, rather than cause, ischemic chest pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-HT Agonist includes medications like triptans (e.g., sumatriptan), which are commonly used in migraine treatment. Triptans are 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists and can cause vasoconstriction of blood vessels. In patients with ischemic heart disease, this vasoconstriction can exacerbate angina (chest pain) or precipitate myocardial infarction, especially if the coronary arteries are already compromised.

choices.text: CO2 retention due to opioid use

questions.text:
A patient presented with pelvic fracture and head trauma after a road traffic accident.

He was given IV morphine for pain relief following which he developed respiratory difficulty. What could be the most likely cause? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CO2 retention due to opioid use


The development of respiratory difficulty in a patient who received IV morphine for pain relief after sustaining a pelvic fracture and head trauma can be due to several reasons.

 

Opioids like morphine can depress the respiratory center in the brain, leading to decreased respiratory rate and tidal volume. This can result in CO2 retention and respiratory difficulty, particularly in higher doses or in patients with pre-existing respiratory issues. This is a well-known side effect of opioids and is a common cause of respiratory depression following opioid administration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic Fracture: While a pelvic fracture can be severe and cause significant pain, it is not typically directly associated with the development of respiratory difficulty unless there are associated injuries, such as a pneumothorax or hemorrhage leading to shock.

 

Option C. Cerebral Edema: Head trauma can lead to cerebral edema, which in turn can affect the brain's respiratory center. However, the onset of respiratory difficulty immediately following opioid administration suggests that the opioid's effects are more likely to be the cause, rather than a progression of cerebral edema, which usually develops over a longer period.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Embolism: A pulmonary embolism (PE) is a possible complication following trauma and immobilization. However, the immediate onset of respiratory difficulty after opioid administration makes PE less likely as the primary cause in this scenario.

 

Considering the timing and circumstances, the most likely cause of the respiratory difficulty in this patient is CO2 Retention due to Opioid Use. Morphine and other opioids can cause respiratory depression, leading to reduced ventilation and CO2 retention.

 

  • The CO2 retention can also increase the ICP. Apart from that, miosis is produced by morphine, which makes it difficult for assessment of neurological status in head trauma patients. Therefore, morphine is contraindicated in head injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opioids like morphine can cause respiratory depression by decreasing the respiratory rate and tidal volume, leading to CO2 retention. This effect is particularly concerning in patients with head trauma due to the potential for increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants causes the least sexual dysfunction? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mirtazapine

 

The typical antidepressants (SSRI, SNRI, MAO inhibitors and TCA) are notorious for causing sexual disturbances like erectile dysfunction due to increased levels of serotonin. On the other hand, atypical anti-depressants (like mirtazapine and bupropion etc) have lesser propensity to cause these adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Fluoxetine: As a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), fluoxetine is commonly associated with sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido, difficulty achieving orgasm, and erectile dysfunction.

 

Options B. Venlafaxine: This is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). While perhaps slightly less likely to cause sexual side effects than SSRIs, venlafaxine can still lead to sexual

dysfunction in a significant number of patients.

 

Options D. Imipramine: A tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), imipramine can cause sexual dysfunction, often due to its anticholinergic effects. TCAs, in general, are more likely to cause a variety of side effects, including those affecting sexual function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant. Apart from increasing the levels of serotonin and nor-adrenaline (due to blockade of presynaptic alpha 2 receptors), It also acts as an antagonist of serotonin (5-HT2 and 5-HT3) receptors. It has some degree of H1 blocking property also. It is therefore known as NSSA (Nor adrenergic and Specific Serotonergic Antidepressant). Mirtazapine is generally associated with a lower incidence of sexual side effects compared to SSRIs and SNRIs, making it a better option for patients concerned about these issues.

choices.text: When used with alcohol, the patients develops nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort and palpitations
It is an anti-craving drug for alcohol
It can be initiated even in minimally motivated person
Its action persists maximum up to 2-3 days after stopping the drug

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about disulfiram? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. When used with alcohol, the patients develops nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort and palpitations

 

Disulfiram, when used concurrently with alcohol, causes an accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body due to its inhibition of the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. This leads to a range of unpleasant symptoms, including nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort, and palpitations, which are part of the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction. This reaction is intentional and serves as a deterrent to alcohol consumption. It is given at a dose of 250mg/day, dose may be increased up to 500 mg/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Disulfiram is not primarily an anti-craving drug for alcohol. It works by creating an aversive reaction to alcohol rather than reducing the craving for alcohol. Medications like naltrexone or acamprosate are more accurately described as anti-craving drugs.

 

Option C. Disulfiram should be prescribed to highly motivated individuals. It requires a commitment to abstain from alcohol due to the serious nature of the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction. It is not typically recommended for individuals who are minimally motivated or likely to continue consuming alcohol.

 

Option D. The action of Disulfiram can persist beyond 2-3 days after stopping the drug. Its inhibitory effect on acetaldehyde dehydrogenase can last for up to a week or more in some cases, making it possible for the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction to occur even several days after the last dose of Disulfiram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disulfiram, when used concurrently with alcohol, causes a severe and unpleasant reaction due to the accumulation of acetaldehyde, including nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort, and palpitations, serving as a deterrent to alcohol consumption. It should be used in highly motivated individuals committed to abstaining from alcohol.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs promotes bone formation? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Teriparatide
 

  • Teriparatide is recombinant PTH analogue that is used in the treatment of osteoporosis. When given in low doses, it stimulates bone formation by mimicking the physiological action of PTH on the osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Calcitonin: Mechanism: Calcitonin inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption. It helps maintain bone density but does not stimulate new bone formation.

 

Options B. Raloxifene: Mechanism: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It inhibits bone resorption by reducing osteoclast activity and is used to prevent bone loss in postmenopausal women, but it does not promote bone formation.

 

Options C. Bisphosphonates: Mechanism: Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate and risedronate, inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. These drugs help maintain bone density and reduce the risk of fractures, but they do not promote new bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS USED IN OSTEOPOROSIS

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient with fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later he presents with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Amoxicillin

 

Out of the options given above, amoxicillin is the only drug which is an antibiotic. It is an amino penicillin. Allergic reactions in the form of skin rashes to Penicillin group of antibiotics are very common, out of which it is the highest with aminopenicillins.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used in the treatment of asthma to reduce inflammation. Corticosteroids like prednisolone are not typically associated with causing maculopapular rashes. In fact, they are often used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

 

Options B. Salbutamol: Also known as albuterol, this is a bronchodilator used to relieve bronchospasm in conditions like asthma. Salbutamol is not commonly associated with skin rashes like a maculopapular rash.

 

Options C. Fexofenadine: This is an antihistamine used for allergic reactions. It is unlikely to cause a maculopapular rash and is more commonly used to treat such rashes when they are due to allergic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amoxicillin, an aminopenicillin antibiotic, is commonly associated with allergic reactions, including maculopapular rashes. This is a well-known side effect of penicillin antibiotics. Prednisolone, salbutamol, and fexofenadine are less likely to cause such reactions, and in the case of prednisolone and fexofenadine, they are actually used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Does not provide multiple doses
﻿﻿﻿Drug deposition in the oropharynx

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Drug deposition in the oropharynx

 

The given image shows a metered-dose inhaler (MDI). It is a common device used for delivering drugs (like inhaled corticosteroids, bronchodilators etc.) used in the management of bronchial asthma and COPD.

 

Drug Deposition in the Oropharynx is a well-recognized limitation of MDIs. A significant proportion of the medication can deposit in the oropharynx and upper airways instead of reaching the lower respiratory tract where it is needed. This not only reduces the efficiency of the drug delivery to the lungs but can also increase the risk of local side effects, such as oral thrush when using corticosteroid inhalers.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Bacterial Contamination: While good hygiene is important in the maintenance of any inhaler device, bacterial contamination is not a commonly cited primary drawback of MDIs. Regular cleaning can typically manage this risk.

 

Options B. Does Not Provide Multiple Doses: This is not accurate. MDIs are designed to provide multiple doses. They contain a pressurized canister that delivers a specific dose of medication in aerosol form with each actuation.

 

Options D. Not Portable: MDIs are actually very portable and convenient, which is one of their advantages. They are compact and easy to carry, making them suitable for use on the go.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common drawback of metered-dose inhalers (MDIs) is drug deposition in the oropharynx, which reduces the efficiency of drug delivery to the lungs and can increase the risk of local side effects.

choices.text: Adequate safety profile needs to be established
Cost to benefit has to be considered
Fixed dose combination of drugs is preferred over single drugs

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the selection of essential drugs? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fixed dose combination of drugs is preferred over single drugs

 

The WHO has defined Essential Medicines (Drugs) as “those that satisfy the priority healthcare needs of the population. They are selected with due regard to public health relevance, evidence on efficacy and safety, and comparative cost effectiveness. Essential medicines are intended to be available within the context of functioning health systems at all times and in adequate amounts, in appropriate dosage forms, with assured quality and adequate information, and at a price the individual and the community can afford.”

 

This is generally false. While fixed-dose combinations (FDCs) can be beneficial in certain scenarios (like in the treatment of HIV/AIDS or tuberculosis), they are not universally preferred over single-drug formulations. The preference for FDCs or single drugs depends on several factors, including the therapeutic context, the risk of drug-drug interactions, patient adherence, and the potential for resistance development. Mostly, single drugs are preferred due to their flexibility in dosing and the ability to adjust individual components based on patient needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adequate safety profile needs to be established: This is true. When selecting essential drugs, it's crucial that they have a well-established safety profile. Safety is a key consideration to ensure that the benefits of a drug outweigh its risks.

 

Option B. Cost to benefit has to be considered: This is also true. In the selection of essential drugs, the cost-effectiveness of a drug is an important factor. The aim is to provide the most effective treatment at the lowest possible cost.

 

Option D. Disease prevalence is considered: This is true. When selecting essential drugs, the prevalence of diseases in a population is an important consideration. Drugs to treat common and life-threatening diseases are typically prioritized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The selection of essential drugs prioritizes factors like safety, cost-effectiveness, and disease prevalence. Fixed-dose combinations are not universally preferred over single drugs, as the choice depends on specific therapeutic needs and other considerations.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with hypertension is diagnosed with stage 4 chronic kidney disease, with eGFR of <30. His doctor wants to prescribe a thiazide diuretic. Which of the following can be given? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Metolazone

 

In the context of a patient with stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD) and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of less than 30 mL/min, the choice of diuretic is important, as not all diuretics are effective in patients with significantly reduced kidney function. Among the thiazides, metolazone remains effective in presence of severe renal failure whereas traditional thiazides like chlorthalidone, hydrochlorothiazide and chlorthiazide are ineffective.

 

The reason Metolazone remains effective in patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD), where traditional thiazide diuretics are less effective, lies in their pharmacokinetic properties and the way they interact with kidney function.

 

Site of Action and Kidney Function:

 

  • Thiazide diuretics primarily act on the distal convoluted tubule in the kidney. They inhibit the sodium-chloride symporter, leading to increased excretion of sodium and chloride, and consequently, water.
  • In advanced CKD, particularly when the eGFR (estimated glomerular filtration rate) falls below 30 mL/min, the kidney function is significantly impaired. Traditional thiazides become less effective because they depend on adequate kidney function to reach their site of action and to exert their diuretic effect.

 

Pharmacokinetics of Metolazone:

 

  • Metolazone is classified as a thiazide-like diuretic. Unlike traditional thiazides, it retains its effectiveness even in patients with reduced kidney function.
  • This is because metolazone has additional actions on the proximal tubule of the kidney, where it inhibits sodium reabsorption. This proximal action is not as dependent on kidney function as the action in the distal tubule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorothiazide: This traditional thiazide diuretic is ineffective in patients with significantly reduced kidney function (eGFR <30 mL/min).

 

Option B. Chlorthalidone: Another traditional thiazide diuretic that is not effective in advanced CKD due to its reliance on adequate kidney function to exert its diuretic effect.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide: Like other traditional thiazides, hydrochlorothiazide is ineffective in patients with severe renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metolazone is the preferred thiazide-like diuretic for patients with stage 4 chronic kidney disease and an eGFR of less than 30 mL/min, as it retains its effectiveness even in the presence of significantly reduced kidney function. This is due to its additional action on the proximal tubule, which is less dependent on kidney function.

choices.text: Increase the dose
Decrease the dose
Stop the drug
Stop retigabine and start on carbamazepine

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with epilepsy was put on retigabine thrice a day. Now phenytoin is being added. Which of the following changes should be made to retigabine therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Increase the dose

 

In the scenario where phenytoin is added to a patient's epilepsy treatment regimen that already includes retigabine, and if one of the provided options must be chosen, the most appropriate choice, based on known pharmacological interactions, would be:

 

  • The rationale for this choice is based on the enzyme-inducing properties of phenytoin. Phenytoin is known to induce hepatic enzymes that metabolize many drugs, potentially leading to reduced levels of these drugs. The general principle of enzyme induction suggests that the levels of retigabine could be decreased when phenytoin is added. Therefore, an increase in the dose of retigabine may be necessary to maintain therapeutic drug levels and effective seizure control.
  • However, it's important to emphasize that any dose adjustment should be made cautiously and based on clinical monitoring, including assessing the efficacy of seizure control and watching for any potential side effects. The decision should be individualized and ideally supported by drug level monitoring if available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease the dose: Decreasing the dose of retigabine would be counterproductive, as the enzyme-inducing effect of phenytoin would lower the drug levels, requiring an increase rather than a decrease.

 

Option C. Stop the drug: Stopping retigabine is not advisable without a clear indication of severe side effects or failure to control seizures. Retigabine can be an effective antiepileptic, and its discontinuation should be based on clinical judgment and not just due to the addition of another drug.

 

Option D. Stop retigabine and start on carbamazepine: This option suggests switching to another antiepileptic drug. While carbamazepine is another enzyme inducer like phenytoin, switching medications is not necessary unless there are specific reasons to do so, such as intolerability or ineffectiveness of retigabine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When phenytoin, an enzyme inducer, is added to a regimen that includes retigabine, the dose of retigabine should be increased to compensate for the increased metabolism and maintain effective seizure control.

choices.text: Downregulation of CYP2C19
Downregulation of CYP2D6
Upregulation of CYP1A1
Downregulation of CYP2E1

questions.text: A patient of 45 year with history of ischemic stroke was started on clopidogrel, However, she had another attack of stroke after 6 months. Which of the following is likely to be responsible for the failure of clopidogrel in this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Downregulation of CYP2C19


Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet drug used to prevent MI and stroke. The failure of clopidogrel in preventing a second stroke in a patient can be influenced by various factors, including genetic variations that affect drug metabolism.

 

Clopidogrel is a prodrug that requires activation by CYP2C19. Genetic polymorphisms or downregulation of CYP2C19 can lead to reduced conversion of clopidogrel to its active form. This results in decreased antiplatelet activity and a higher risk of thrombotic events, such as stroke. Individuals with reduced function alleles of CYP2C19 are known as "poor metabolizers," and in these patients, clopidogrel may be less effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Downregulation of CYP2D6: While CYP2D6 is important for the metabolism of many drugs, it is not primarily responsible for the activation of clopidogrel. Therefore, downregulation of CYP2D6 would not significantly impact clopidogrel's effectiveness.

 

Option C. Upregulation of CYP1A1: CYP1A1 is not involved in the metabolism of clopidogrel. Its upregulation would not affect the activation of clopidogrel or its therapeutic efficacy.

 

Option D. Downregulation of CYP2E1: CYP2E1 is involved in the metabolism of ethanol and certain other drugs but does not play a significant role in the activation of clopidogrel. Therefore, downregulation of CYP2E1 would not impact clopidogrel's effectiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The failure of clopidogrel in preventing a second stroke in a patient may be due to the downregulation of CYP2C19. This enzyme is crucial for converting clopidogrel into its active form, and its reduced activity can lead to decreased antiplatelet effects and increased risk of thrombotic events.

questions.text: Which of the following can be given for long term management of obesity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Liraglutide

 

Liraglutide is an injectable medication originally developed to treat type 2 diabetes but has also been approved for weight management in obesity. It works by mimicking the hormone GLP-1, which regulates appetite and calorie intake. Liraglutide has been shown to be effective for long-term weight management and is considered a viable option for obesity treatment.

 

Other Options:
