Option B. Metformin: While metformin is primarily used to treat type 2 diabetes, it has been observed to cause modest weight loss in some people. However, it is not primarily indicated for the treatment of obesity and is usually not the first choice solely for weight management.

 

Option C. Sibutramine: Sibutramine was previously used as an appetite suppressant for weight loss, but it has been withdrawn from the market in many countries due to cardiovascular safety concerns. Therefore, it is no longer recommended for obesity treatment.

 

Option D. Fenfluramine: Part of the fen-phen combination, fenfluramine was used for weight loss but was withdrawn from the market due to serious side effects, particularly heart valve issues. Like sibutramine, it is no longer considered safe or appropriate for obesity treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liraglutide is a viable and approved option for the long-term management of obesity. It works by mimicking the hormone GLP-1 to help regulate appetite and reduce calorie intake. Other Options like sibutramine and fenfluramine have been withdrawn from the market due to safety concerns, and metformin, while causing modest weight loss, is not primarily indicated for obesity treatment.

choices.text: Treatment of migraine
Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome
Prophylaxis of ADHD
Treatment of dementia

questions.text: Topiramate is used for? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome

 

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that can be used for the treatment of Lennaux-Gestaut Syndrome (characterized by multifocal seizures, having <2.5 Hz spike and wave pattern in EEG). It primarily works by blocking the Na+ channels, and to some extent it also enhances the GABA receptor currents and limiting the activation of the AMPA-kainate subtype of glutamate receptors.

 

Topiramate can also be used for:

 

  • C: Decreasing the Craving of alcohol
  • O: Obesity
  • M: Migraine Prophylaxis (not treatment)
  • B: Bipolar disorder.

 

So, among the given options, best answer is Lennox Gastaut syndrome. Do not get confused with migraine as the options specifically mentions the treatment of migraine whereas topiramate is used for prophylaxis of migraine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment of migraine: Topiramate is used for the prophylaxis of migraines, not for the acute treatment of migraine attacks.

 

Option C. Prophylaxis of ADHD: Topiramate is not indicated for the prophylaxis or treatment of ADHD.

 

Option D. Treatment of dementia: Topiramate is not used for the treatment of dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topiramate is primarily used for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy in children. It is also used for the prophylaxis of migraines, reducing alcohol cravings, aiding in weight loss, and as an adjunct therapy for bipolar disorder.

choices.text: Area under the curve

questions.text: The extent of drug absorption in plasma concentration vs time graph is represented by:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Area under the curve

 

Area under the curve (AUC) is a measure of the total drug exposure in the bloodstream over time. It reflects the total amount of drug absorbed and is often used to assess the overall bioavailability of a drug. AUC is crucial for determining the efficacy and safety of a medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tmax (Time to Maximum Concentration): Tmax represents the time it takes for a drug to reach its maximum concentration (Cmax) in the bloodstream. It tells about rate of drug absorption.

 

Option C. Cmax (Maximum Concentration): Cmax represents the highest concentration of a drug in the bloodstream after administration. This parameter is important because it indicates the peak therapeutic effect and helps assess the risk of side effects associated with high drug concentrations.

 

Option D. t1/2 (Half-Life): t1/2 is the time it takes for half of the drug to be eliminated from the bloodstream. It is not directly related to drug absorption but is essential in understanding how long a drug remains in the body and how often it needs to be administered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Area Under the Curve (AUC) in a plasma concentration vs. time graph represents the extent of drug absorption, reflecting the total drug exposure over time and the overall bioavailability of the drug.

choices.text: Drug 1 represents agonist and drug 2 represents inverse agonist﻿﻿﻿
Drug 3 represents agonist and drug 4 represents inverse agonist
﻿﻿﻿Drug 1 represents agonist and drug 4 represents inverse agonist
﻿﻿﻿Drug 2 represents partial agonist and drug 3 represents inverse agonist

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding the given graph?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Drug 1 represents agonist and drug 4 represents inverse agonist

 

Drug 1 = Full agonist, showing the maximal effect, having an intrinsic efficacy of +1

 

E.g., Salbutamol is a β2 receptor agonist

 

Drug 2 = Partial agonist, produces submaximal effect and has an intrinsic efficacy in the range of 0 to +1. E.g., Buprenorphine at the opioid receptors.

 

Drug 3 = Antagonist, having no effect of its own at the receptor, that is an intrinsic efficacy of 0.

 

E.g., Naltrexone and Naloxone at the opioid receptors.

 

Drug 4 = Inverse agonist, produces opposite effect and has a negative intrinsic efficacy.

 

E.g., Beta-Carboline is an inverse agonist at benzodiazepine site of GABA-A receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug 1: Shows the highest level of response, indicating it is a full agonist.

 

Drug 2: Shows a submaximal response, indicating it is a partial agonist.

 

Drug 3: Shows no change in response, indicating it is an antagonist.

 

Drug 4: Shows a negative response, indicating it is an inverse agonist.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is the new FDA approved immune check point inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pembrolizumab

 

The new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium is Pembrolizumab.

 

Pembrolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against PD-1 receptor (Programmed Death Receptor) that can be used for many cancers including endometrial carcinoma. Some of the other cancers where it is useful are:

 

  • Metastatic urothelial cancer
  • Refractory melanoma
  • Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Merkel cell cancer
  • Chemotherapy Refractory Head and Neck Cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab: is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and is used for the treatment of advanced melanoma and relapsed/refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option C. Trastuzumab: is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the HER2 receptor. It is used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Option D. Ipilimumab: is a monoclonal antibody that binds to cytotoxic T lymphocyte-associated Protein 4 (CTLA-4) and is approved for the treatment of late-stage melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pembrolizumab is the new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium. It works by blocking the PD-1 receptor, enhancing the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells. It is also used for treating several other cancers, including metastatic urothelial cancer, refractory melanoma, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Merkel cell cancer, and chemotherapy-refractory head and neck cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an immune checkpoint inhibitor? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cetuximab 

 

Cetuximab is a monoclonal antibody against EGFR (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor). It is used in the treatment of Colorectal and Head and Neck Cancers. It is not an immune check point inhibitor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and are used for the treatment of advanced melanoma and classical Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option B. Pembrolizumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor

- 1 (PD-1) and are used for the treatment of advanced melanoma.

 

Option C. Atezolimumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It acts by inhibiting programmed death-ligand - 1 (PDL-1) and is used for the treatment of urothelial, breast and non-small cell lung cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important immune check point inhibitors include:

 

New:                Nivolumab

Drugs:              Durvalumab

Act:                  Avelumab

At:                   Atezolizumab

Immune:          Ipilimumab

Check:             Cemiplimab

Point:               Pembrolizumab

questions.text: NAPQI is the metabolite of which of the following drug toxicity? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Paracetamol


N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) is a metabolite of paracetamol drug toxicity.

 

NAPQI is highly reactive and has high affinity for sulfydryl groups. It causes enzymatic dysfunction in the liver. Normally, minor amounts of NAPQI produced in our body are rapidly eliminated by conjugation with reduced glutathione (GSH) that acts as a source of sulfhydryl group and then excreted into the urine.

 

Therefore, paracetamol toxicity is treated with N-acetyl cysteine (NAC), which provides the sulfhydryl group. NAC thereby helps in the excretion of NAPQI from the body.

 

The maximum recommended dose of acetaminophen is 4g/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin toxicity is not associated with NAPQI. Aspirin overdose primarily causes metabolic acidosis, respiratory alkalosis, and can lead to salicylate poisoning.

 

Option C. Diclofenac: Diclofenac toxicity does not involve NAPQI. Diclofenac is an NSAID that can cause gastrointestinal and renal toxicity.

 

Option D. Ketorolac: Ketorolac toxicity is not associated with NAPQI. Like other NSAIDs, ketorolac can cause gastrointestinal bleeding and renal toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NAPQI is a toxic metabolite produced during the metabolism of paracetamol. In cases of paracetamol overdose, NAPQI accumulates and causes liver damage. The antidote for paracetamol toxicity is N-acetylcysteine (NAC), which helps detoxify NAPQI by replenishing glutathione and providing sulfhydryl groups.

choices.text: Hydralazine - heart failure
Atenolol - hemolytic anemia
Aliskiren - hypokalemia

questions.text: Identify the correct match, regarding the drug and its adverse effect?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Verapamil – constipation


The correct match regarding the drug and its adverse effect (read carefully, they have not asked the indication) is verapamil causes constipation.

 

Verapamil is a Non DHP calcium channel blocker. It can cause constipation as its side effect.


Other Options:


Option A. Hydralazine is a vasodilator which can cause drug-induced lupus. It does not cause heart failure as an adverse effect, rather It is used in treatment of heart failure.


Option B. Atenolol is a cardio selective beta blocker. Bradycardia can be seen as a side effect, not hemolytic anemia. Hemolytic anemia is a side effect of methyl dopa.


Option C. Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor. The side effect of aliskiren is hyperkalemia and not hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verapamil, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, is associated with constipation as a common adverse effect. Other drugs and their incorrect matches in this context include hydralazine (which can cause drug-induced lupus), atenolol (which does not cause hemolytic anemia), and aliskiren (which can cause hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia).

choices.text: 1 month
3 months
No need to stop
Can be stopped and conceived soon after stopping

questions.text: A lady who had undergone mastectomy for breast cancer is being treated with tamoxifen. How long should it be stopped for before she can conceive?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 months

 

  • Tamoxifen is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM), which is used in Premenopausal women having ER +ve breast cancer, because of its anti-estrogenic action in the breast. It prevents the chance of recurrence of breast cancer after surgery.
  • The half-life of tamoxifen is approximately 5 to 7 days, but its active metabolites can persist in the body for several weeks. To minimize any risk to a potential pregnancy, it is recommended to stop tamoxifen at least 3 months before trying to conceive.
  • Tamoxifen has teratogenic effects, such as craniofacial abnormalities and reproductive tract abnormalities. It is also stopped during lactation as it is secreted in breast milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen should be stopped for at least 3 months before attempting to conceive due to its long half-life and potential teratogenic effects. This ensures that the drug and its active metabolites are sufficiently cleared from the body, reducing the risk of harm to the fetus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is diagnosed with breast cancer. Her tumor is found to be HER2-positive but estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) negative. The tumor was resistant to trastuzumab. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be effective in the treatment of this patient's breast cancer?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lapatinib

 

Lapatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that can be used for the treatment of HER2-positive but trastuzumab-resistant breast cancer. Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that is commonly used for the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer, but some patients may develop resistance to this drug over time. Lapatinib works by targeting the HER2 receptor, which is overexpressed in HER2-positive breast cancer, and can be effective in treating breast cancer that has become resistant to trastuzumab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sorafenib is a kinase inhibitor that is primarily used for the treatment of advanced liver cancer and kidney cancer. It works by blocking the activity of several proteins that promote the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Option C. Vismodegib is a hedgehog pathway inhibitor that is used for the treatment of basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer. It works by blocking the hedgehog signalling pathway, which is involved in the development and growth of cancer cells.

 

Option D. Erlotinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that is used for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, pancreatic cancer, and other types of cancer. It works by blocking the activity of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which is involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lapatinib is an effective treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer, especially in cases where the cancer has become resistant to trastuzumab. It works by targeting the HER2 receptor and can help manage this specific type of breast cancer.

choices.text: Matzke scale
Salazar scale
Rummack-mathew scale

questions.text: Vancomycin nomogram is known as (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Matzke scale

 

The Vancomycin nomogram is also known as the Matzke nomogram or the Matzke scale. It is a tool used to help predict the appropriate dose of vancomycin, an antibiotic, based on the patient's creatinine clearance and trough serum concentration. The nomogram is a graphical representation that allows healthcare providers to quickly and easily determine the optimal dose of vancomycin for a given patient, taking into account factors such as kidney function and the patient's weight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salazar scale: This nomogram is not related to vancomycin dosing. It is used to predict overall survival of patients with cancer.

 

Option C. Rummack-Matthew scale: This is used to assess potential hepatotoxicity after acetaminophen intake based on serum acetaminophen concentration.

 

Option D. Krutzko scale: There is no widely recognized medical scale or nomogram known as the Krutzko scale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vancomycin nomogram, also known as the Matzke scale, is a crucial tool for determining the appropriate dosing of vancomycin based on creatinine clearance and trough serum concentration, ensuring both efficacy and safety in patient treatment.

choices.text: The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in an individual.
The range of doses at which a drug is effective without causing significant adverse effects.
The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in a population.
The dosage at which a drug is both safe and effective in the majority of patients.

questions.text: Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is best described as: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in a population.

 

The Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is best described as the ratio of the median lethal dose (LD50) to the median effective dose (ED50). Both LD50 and ED50 are calculated by checking different doses in a population.

 

  • It represents the margin of safety of a drug. A higher Clinical Therapeutic Index indicates that a drug has a greater margin of safety, and can be given at higher doses without causing significant adverse effects.
  • The Clinical Therapeutic Index is an important consideration in the development and use of new medications, and helps healthcare providers determine the appropriate dose for individual patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in an individual: This description is incorrect because the therapeutic index is determined based on population data, not individual data.

 

Option B. The range of doses at which a drug is effective without causing significant adverse effects: This describes the therapeutic window or therapeutic range, not the therapeutic index.

 

Option D. The dosage at which a drug is both safe and effective in the majority of patients: This is a general description of an effective and safe dosage regimen but does not specifically describe the therapeutic index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is the ratio of the median lethal dose (LD50) to the median effective dose (ED50) in a population, representing the drug's margin of safety. A higher Therapeutic Index indicates a greater margin of safety.

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the receptors they act upon: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2

 

 

Other Options:

 

A-3. Mirabegron acts on β3 receptors. Mirabegron is a β3 adrenergic receptor agonist used for the treatment of bladder incontinence by relaxing the detrusor muscle during the storage phase of the urinary bladder fill-void cycle.

 

B-4. Indacaterol acts on β2 receptors. Indacaterol is a long-acting β2 adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

 

C-1. Betaxolol acts on β1 receptors. Betaxolol is a β1 selective blocker used in the treatment of hypertension and glaucoma.

 

D-2. Isoproterenol acts on β1 β2 receptors. Isoproterenol is a non-selective β adrenergic agonist with no α action, used in the treatment of bradycardia and heart block.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

questions.text: Mechanism of thalidomide teratogenicity include all except
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

 

Thalidomide actually suppresses the production of certain cytokines, including IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5. The suppression of these interleukins is part of its immunomodulatory effects, not a mechanism of teratogenicity. Thalidomide suppresses the production of interleukins which is an important mechanism in treatment of multiple myeloma.

 

The exact mechanism of thalidomide's teratogenicity is not completely understood, but several mechanisms have been proposed:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of angiogenesis: Thalidomide has been found to inhibit angiogenesis, which is the formation of new blood vessels. This inhibition can disrupt the development of the fetus, leading to birth defects. This mechanism is widely accepted as a significant contributor to the teratogenic effects of thalidomide.

 

Option C. Generation of oxygen free radicals: Thalidomide may cause oxidative stress by generating oxygen free radicals, which can damage developing cells. This oxidative stress can contribute to teratogenic effects.

 

Option D. Binding to cereblon: Recent studies have shown that thalidomide binds to a protein called cereblon, which is involved in limb outgrowth and ear development. When thalidomide binds to cereblon, it disrupts the normal function of this protein, leading to the birth defects associated with thalidomide use.

 

Other mechanism includes -

 

  • Interference with cellular signalling: Thalidomide may interfere with various cellular signalling pathways, such as those involving fibroblast growth factors, which are important for embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thalidomide's teratogenicity is primarily associated with mechanisms such as the inhibition of angiogenesis, generation of oxygen free radicals, and binding to the cereblon protein. It does not cause an increase in IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5; in fact, it suppresses these interleukins.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC). Molecular testing reveals a specific mutation in the EGFR gene. The oncologist is considering using targeted therapy. For which of the following EGFR mutations is Osimertinib most appropriately used to treat non-small cell lung carcinoma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. T790M mutation

 

Osimertinib is a third-generation epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) that is particularly effective in treating non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) patients who have developed resistance to first-generation EGFR inhibitors (such as gefitinib or erlotinib) due to the T790M mutation in the EGFR gene. This mutation is a common mechanism of acquired resistance, and Osimertinib is specifically designed to target it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. L858R mutation is another common EGFR mutation seen in NSCLC. Although Osimertinib can also be used for L858R mutations, it is not specifically indicated as the primary treatment for this mutation. First-generation EGFR inhibitors like gefitinib or erlotinib are often used for L858R mutations.

 

Option C. T890M mutation and Option D. M790T mutation are not recognized mutations associated with EGFR in the context of NSCLC, and there is no evidence to suggest that Osimertinib is used for these mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitters is released from SA node in response to increase in blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acetylcholine

 

Acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter released by the parasympathetic nervous system. When blood pressure increases, baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch detect this change and stimulate the parasympathetic nervous system. This leads to the release of acetylcholine from the vagus nerve at the SA node, resulting in a decrease in heart rate (bradycardia) and a reduction in cardiac output, which helps to lower blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dopamine: Dopamine is a neurotransmitter involved in several central nervous system functions, including movement and reward. It is not directly involved in the regulation of heart rate or blood pressure in the context of the SA node.

 

Option C. Epinephrine: Epinephrine (adrenaline) is released by the adrenal medulla and acts on both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors. It generally increases heart rate and blood pressure. It is not released from the SA node in response to increased blood pressure.

 

Option D. Norepinephrine: Norepinephrine is a neurotransmitter released by the sympathetic nervous system. It acts on alpha and beta adrenergic receptors to increase heart rate and blood pressure. However, in response to increased blood pressure, the sympathetic activity is typically reduced, and norepinephrine release is decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the correct neurotransmitter released from the SA node in response to an increase in blood pressure is acetylcholine, as it is part of the parasympathetic response to decrease heart rate and lower blood pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in treatment of leprosy can result in hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clofazimine

 

Clofazimine is known to cause hyperpigmentation of the skin. This drug is used in leprosy treatment for its anti-inflammatory properties and its ability to kill Mycobacterium leprae. Clofazimine can lead to a characteristic reddish-brown to black discoloration of the skin, which can be quite distressing to patients but is usually harmless.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dapsone: Dapsone is an antibiotic commonly used in the treatment of leprosy. While it has various side effects, hyperpigmentation is not typically associated with dapsone. Common side effects include hemolysis (especially in individuals with G6PD deficiency) and peripheral neuropathy.

 

Option B. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that can be used as part of alternative regimens for leprosy. Hyperpigmentation is not a known side effect of ofloxacin. Its common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances and tendinitis.

 

Option C. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is another cornerstone drug in the treatment of leprosy. It can cause orange-red discoloration of body fluids (such as urine, sweat, and tears), but it does not typically cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In this case, the patient's hyperpigmentation is most likely due to clofazimine. This side effect is well-documented and is a result of the drug accumulating in the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect with the long-term use of intermittent teriparatide for treatment of osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

Osteosarcoma is a rare but serious potential adverse effect associated with the long-term use of teriparatide. This risk was identified in animal studies where high doses of teriparatide caused osteosarcoma in rats. Although this effect has not been conclusively demonstrated in humans, the potential risk has led to caution in prescribing teriparatide for long durations, usually limited to a maximum of 2 years of use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteonecrosis of the jaw bone: Osteonecrosis of the jaw is more commonly associated with bisphosphonates and denosumab, not with teriparatide. Teriparatide, being a parathyroid hormone analog, does not typically cause this condition.

 

Option C. Subtrochanteric fracture: Subtrochanteric fractures are more commonly associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates rather than teriparatide. Teriparatide, by stimulating new bone formation, is less likely to cause these types of fractures.

 

Option D. Loss of bone mass: Teriparatide is used to increase bone mass and strength by stimulating bone formation. Loss of bone mass is not a recognized adverse effect of teriparatide; rather, the medication is prescribed to counteract this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the most significant potential adverse effect associated with the long-term use of teriparatide is the development of osteosarcoma, albeit this risk is based primarily on animal studies. Therefore, clinicians are advised to limit the duration of teriparatide therapy and monitor patients closely.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor. SGLT2 inhibitors work by promoting the excretion of glucose through the urine. This increased urinary glucose can create an environment that promotes the growth of bacteria, thereby increasing the risk of urinary tract infections. This class of drugs is well known for its association with UTIs and genital infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It works by increasing incretin levels, which in turn increase insulin secretion and decrease glucagon secretion. Sitagliptin is not commonly associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects of metformin include gastrointestinal disturbances such as diarrhea and abdominal discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This patient’s recurrent UTIs could be related to her use of dapagliflozin.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a history of hyperglycemia and has had positive urine glucose tests on two separate occasions in the last six months. The patient has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The physician is considering various medications to manage the patient's condition and prevent potential complications, including renal involvement. Which of the following drugs will not delay renal involvement? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

  • Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used to treat hypertension. 
  • While effective at lowering blood pressure, it does not have specific renal protective effects and may not delay the progression of renal disease in diabetic patients. 
  • In fact, in some cases, thiazide diuretics can increase the risk of developing hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SGLT2 inhibitors: SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., canagliflozin, dapagliflozin) are a class of medications used to lower blood sugar in patients with type 2 diabetes. They work by promoting glucose excretion through the urine. Importantly, SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to provide renal protection and delay the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

 

Option B. Finerenone: It is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist that reduces inflammation and fibrosis in the kidneys. Clinical trials have demonstrated that finerenone can reduce the risk of kidney disease progression in patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.

 

Option D. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs): ARBs (e.g., losartan, valsartan) are another class of medications used to manage hypertension and heart failure. Like ACE inhibitors, ARBs have been shown to provide renal protection and delay the progression of diabetic nephropathy by reducing proteinuria and lowering intraglomerular pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, while SGLT2 inhibitors, ACE inhibitors, and ARBs have renal protective properties and can help delay renal involvement in diabetic patients, hydrochlorothiazide does not have these specific protective effects and is the correct answer in this context.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

  • Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. 
  • It is well known to cause gastrointestinal side effects, including diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal discomfort, particularly when first starting the medication or when the dose is increased. 
  • Diarrhea is one of the most common side effects of metformin and can sometimes be severe or persistent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not commonly associated with diarrhea. Its common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option B. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analog used as an adjunct treatment for diabetes. It slows gastric emptying and promotes satiety but is not typically associated with diarrhea. Nausea is a more common gastrointestinal side effect.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion from the pancreas. It is not known to cause diarrhea. Hypoglycemia is its most significant side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, metformin is the anti-diabetic drug most commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea. The patient's symptoms are likely related to metformin use.

choices.text: Safety in pregnancy
Dose adjustment in renal failure
Cost ratio from cheap to expensive
As per safety or therapeutic index

questions.text: Category A, B, C, D, X in drug classification is indicative of which of the following?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Safety in pregnancy

 

The categories A, B, C, D, and X are used to classify drugs based on their safety during pregnancy. This classification helps in determining the potential risk of medications to the fetus when taken during pregnancy.

 

Pregnancy drug category, which are indicative of their safety are as follows:

 

Category A > B > C > D > X

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dose adjustment in renal failure: Drug classifications for dose adjustments in renal failure typically involve guidelines based on the drug's pharmacokinetics and renal clearance. These guidelines are not categorized as A, B, C, D, X.

 

Option C. Cost ratio from cheap to expensive: Drug classifications based on cost are not typically denoted by the categories A, B, C, D, X. Cost-related classifications might be discussed in economic terms or based on generic versus brand name distinctions.

 

Option D. As per safety or therapeutic index: The therapeutic index of a drug, which measures its safety margin, is not categorized using the A, B, C, D, X system. The therapeutic index is a ratio comparing the toxic dose to the therapeutic dose, but it is not classified in this alphabetical manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of drugs into categories A, B, C, D, and X is specifically used to indicate their safety during pregnancy, helping healthcare providers to make informed decisions about medication use in pregnant patients.

choices.text: The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition
The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible
They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design
The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding suicidal inhibition? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition

 

SUICIDE INHIBTION

 

Suicide inhibition, also known as mechanism-based inhibition, is a unique and fascinating aspect of enzyme kinetics. It's a process where an enzyme binds to a substrate analogue, which initially seems like a normal substrate to the enzyme. However, as the enzyme starts to act on this 'pseudo-substrate,' a chemical reaction occurs that modifies the enzyme in such a way that it becomes irreversibly inactivated. This process is termed 'suicide' because the enzyme actively participates in its own inhibition.

 

STEPS INVOLVED IN SUICIDE INHIBITION

 

  1. Binding: The suicide substrate, which is often structurally similar to the actual substrate, binds to the enzyme's active site.
  2. Initial Reaction: The enzyme catalyses a reaction on this substrate analogue, similar to how it would act on its natural substrate.
  3. Formation of Reactive Intermediate: This reaction, however, leads to the formation of a chemically reactive intermediate. This intermediate is the key to the suicide inhibition mechanism.
  4. Modification of Enzyme: The reactive intermediate then reacts with the enzyme itself, leading to a covalent modification of the enzyme. This modification typically occurs at the active site, crucial for the enzyme's activity.
  5. Irreversible Inhibition: As a result of this modification, the enzyme is irreversibly inactivated. It can no longer bind to its natural substrate or catalyse the reaction it was designed for.
  6. Specificity: One of the key features of suicide inhibition is its specificity. Because the inhibitor is structurally similar to the natural substrate, the process is highly specific to the targeted enzyme. This makes suicide inhibitors very effective as drugs, as they can selectively target and inactivate specific enzymes in the body.

 

Other Options:

Option B. The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible: This is true. The substrate analogue binds irreversibly to the enzyme, leading to its permanent inactivation.

 

Option C. They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design: This is true. Suicide inhibitors are designed to be highly specific for the target enzyme, making them valuable in rational drug design.

 

Option D. The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it: This is true. The enzyme catalyzes the conversion of the substrate analogue to a reactive intermediate, which then irreversibly modifies the enzyme, leading to its inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CLINICAL IMPORTANCE

 

Suicide inhibitors have significant implications in drug development, especially for designing drugs that target enzymes involved in disease processes. For instance, certain antibiotics work by suicide inhibition of bacterial enzymes, and some drugs used in the treatment of hypertension and depression also act through this mechanism.

 

Understanding the mechanism of suicide inhibition helps in the development of more effective and specific drugs, with fewer off-target effects. It's a powerful example of how knowledge of biochemistry can be applied in medicinal chemistry and pharmacology.

 

EXAMPLES OF SUICIDE INHIBITORS

 

  • Beta lactams (Penicillins)
  • Aspirin
  • Allopurinol
  • MAO inhibitors

choices.text: 2-10 mcg/kg/min
< 2 mcg/kg/min
10-20 mcg/kg/min

questions.text: The dose at which dopamine acts on beta 1 receptors is:(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2-10 mcg/kg/min

 

2-10 mcg/kg/min is the correct dose range at which dopamine primarily acts on beta 1 receptors in the heart, enhancing cardiac output by increasing heart rate and contractility.

 

Dopamine acts upon 3 receptors depending upon the dose:

 

D1 – < 2 mcg/kg/min (Present in the blood vessels of the kidney in highest concentration - Vasodilation and increased renal blood flow)

 

β1 – 2-10 mcg/kg/min (Present in the heart - Increased heart rate and contractility, which improves cardiac output)

 

α1 – >10 mcg/kg/min (Present in blood vessels - Vasoconstriction, which increases blood pressure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. < 2 mcg/kg/min: At this dose, dopamine primarily acts on D1 receptors, causing vasodilation and increased renal blood flow without significant effects on the heart.

 

Option C. 10-20 mcg/kg/min: At this higher dose, dopamine acts predominantly on alpha 1 receptors, causing vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure.

 

Option D. > 20 mcg/kg/min: Similar to the previous option, at doses higher than 20 mcg/kg/min, dopamine continues to exert effects primarily on alpha 1 receptors, resulting in significant vasoconstriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dopamine has dose-dependent receptor selectivity. It acts on beta 1 receptors at doses of 2-10 mcg/kg/min, increasing cardiac output by enhancing heart rate and contractility.

choices.text: Causes monofollicular development
Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH
Causes endometrial thinning
Can be used with gonadotropins

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding clomiphene citrate? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Causes monofollicular development
 

  • Clomiphene citrate is SERM (Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator) that inhibits the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, which in turn leads to an increase in LH/FSH, and this helps in the development of multiple follicles in the ovary. Clomiphene is used in the treatment of anovulatory infertility.
  • Due to its anti-estrogenic action over the endometrium, it causes thickening of the cervical mucus and thinning of the endometrium.
  • Sometimes for ovulation induction, gonadotropins can be used with clomiphene, but it has a risk of giving rise to multiple pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate inhibits the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, which increases the release of GnRH, and subsequently increases LH and FSH secretion from the pituitary gland.

 

Option C. Causes endometrial thinning: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate has an anti-estrogenic effect on the endometrium, which can lead to thinning of the endometrial lining, potentially impacting embryo implantation.

 

Option D. Can be used with gonadotropins: This statement is correct. Clomiphene can be used in combination with gonadotropins for ovulation induction, but this approach increases the risk of multiple pregnancies due to the stimulation of multiple follicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clomiphene citrate induces ovulation by inhibiting the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, leading to increased secretion of gonadotropins and the development of multiple follicles. It can cause endometrial thinning and can be used with gonadotropins, but it does not cause monofollicular development.

choices.text: RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibition
RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibition
Fusion inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of remdesivir? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibition
 

  • Remdesivir is the only FDA approved drug for COVID-19, which is recommended for moderate to severe COVID-19 patients, hospitalized patients, patients on oxygen therapy and should be used within 10 days of disease onset, after which it has no proven benefit.
  • It inhibits RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
  • While on treatment, monitoring of LFT, KFT and PT are required. It should be avoided in pregnant or lactating females, patients less than 12 years of age, if eGFR <30ml/min or ALT>5 times.
  • Adverse effects include anaphylaxis, nausea and infusion related reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibition: This mechanism is not relevant for remdesivir. RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibition is associated with drugs targeting retroviruses, like reverse transcriptase inhibitors used in HIV treatment.

 

Option C. Fusion inhibition: Fusion inhibitors prevent the virus from fusing with the host cell membrane, thereby blocking entry into the cell. This is not the mechanism of remdesivir. An example of a fusion inhibitor is enfuvirtide, used in HIV treatment.

 

Option D. Entry inhibition: Entry inhibitors block the virus from entering the host cell. This is also not the mechanism of action for remdesivir. An example of an entry inhibitor is maraviroc, which is used in HIV treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remdesivir works by inhibiting RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, thus preventing viral RNA replication in COVID-19 patients. It is important to monitor liver and kidney function during treatment and be aware of its contraindications and potential adverse effects.

choices.text: Vitamin C

questions.text: Administration of which of the following drugs would increase the bioavailability of saquinavir? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ritonavir


 

  • Both Ritonavir and Saquinavir are Protease inhibitors that can be used in the treatment of HIV.
  • They are metabolized by the hepatic CYP3A4 enzyme system. But at the same time, Ritonavir is also an inhibitor of CYP3A4. Therefore, if small doses of Ritonavir are added along with Saquinavir, it will inhibit the metabolism of Saquinavir or in other words will boost the bioavailability and concentration of Saquinavir.

choices.text: Drug A decreases intestinal absorption of Drug B
﻿﻿﻿Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of Drug B
﻿﻿﻿Drug A increases the metabolism of Drug B
Drug A increases renal elimination of Drug B

questions.text: The table below gives the AUC of drug B alone and that of drug B when combined with another drug A. If the p value is <0.01, then which of the following statements is true? (INICET 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of Drug B
 

  • The area under the curve or AUC in plasma concentration vs time graph can be used as a measure of the bioavailability of a drug. The bioavailability of a given drug refers to the fraction of the given dose which reaches the systemic circulation. The greater the area under the curve or AUC, the greater is the bioavailability.
  • From the given data, it is seen that the AUC for Drug B is less than the AUC for Drug A + Drug B. And the p value <0.01 indicates that the data is statistically significant. (As the p value is <0.05)
  • So, it can be inferred that the Drug A increases the bioavailability of drug B.

 

As bioavailability depends on two factors:

 

  • Absorption (Bioavailability is directly proportional to the rate of drug absorption)
  • First Pass Metabolism (Bioavailability is inversely proportional to the rate of first pass metabolism of the drug)
  • Therefore, it can be assumed that drug B either increase the absorption or decrease the first pass metabolism of drug A.
  • So among the given options, best answer seem to be option B: Drug A reduces the first pass metabolism of drug B

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug A decreases intestinal absorption of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A decreased the intestinal absorption of Drug B, the AUC would be lower when the drugs are combined, not higher.

 

Option C. Drug A increases the metabolism of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A increased the metabolism of Drug B, the AUC would be lower when the drugs are combined.

 

Option D. Drug A increases renal elimination of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A increased the renal elimination of Drug B, it would lead to a decrease in AUC, not an increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The increase in the AUC of Drug B when combined with Drug A, with a statistically significant p value, indicates that Drug A reduces the first pass metabolism of Drug B, thereby increasing its bioavailability.

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers

questions.text: Urinary alkalinization will be most useful in toxicity of which of the following drugs? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin
 

Urinary alkalinization is a key treatment in aspirin toxicity. Aspirin (salicylate) is a weak acid, and alkalinizing the urine increases the ionization of salicylates. This ionization traps salicylates in the urine, preventing their reabsorption and enhancing their elimination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: Urinary alkalinization is not a standard treatment for beta blocker toxicity. Management of beta blocker overdose typically involves supportive care and, in severe cases, specific antidotes like glucagon or high-dose insulin.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Similar to beta blockers, urinary alkalinization is not a primary treatment for calcium channel blocker overdose. Treatment often includes calcium infusions, glucagon, and other supportive measures.

 

Option C. Acetaminophen: For acetaminophen toxicity, the antidote N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is used. Urinary alkalinization is not effective for acetaminophen overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary alkalinization is most useful in the treatment of aspirin (salicylate) toxicity because it increases the elimination of salicylates by trapping them in the urine through ionization. This method is not effective for beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, or acetaminophen toxicity.

questions.text: A hospital is investigating the effectiveness of statins in a multiple-centric clinical trial. The study involves 4000-5000 patients and half of them have received the drug while the other half was given a placebo. Both the subjects and the investigators are unaware of which group is getting the drug and which group is being administered the placebo. Which of the following phases of clinical trial corresponds to this scenario? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Phase 3  


As the study is being conducted in multiple centers in a double blinded manner, where neither the physician nor the patients know what they are receiving, therefore this trial is in Phase 3.

 

The phases of clinical trials are as follows: -

 

 

  • Phase Zero trials are called micro-dosing studies. It is an optional trial done by some companies on small number of healthy volunteers to know the pharmacokinetics of the drug. Dose used is one-hundredth of the final human dose or 100 microgram (whichever is lower).
  • Pre-clinical trials are animal studies. The drugs are first tested on the small animals like rats, guinea pig etc. to know the complete pharmacokinetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The described clinical trial, with its large sample size, multiple centers, double-blind design, and focus on confirming the efficacy of statins, corresponds to a Phase 3 clinical trial. This phase is crucial for determining whether the drug is effective and safe for widespread use.
